class.name: ObjectArrayList

javadoc.text: Resizable list holding Object elements; implemented with arrays. * First see the package summary and javadoc tree view to get the broad picture.
The array buffer into which the elements of the list are stored. * The capacity of the list is the length of this array buffer.
The size of the list.
Constructs an empty list.

Constructs a list containing the specified elements. * The initial size and capacity of the list is the length of the array. * WARNING: For efficiency reasons and to keep memory usage low, the array is not copied. * So if subsequently you modify the specified array directly via the [] operator, be sure you know what you're doing.
javadoc.param: elements the array to be backed by the the constructed list

javadoc.text: Constructs an empty list with the specified initial capacity.
javadoc.param: initialCapacity the number of elements the receiver can hold without auto-expanding itself by allocating new internal memory.

javadoc.text: Appends the specified element to the end of this list.
javadoc.param: element element to be appended to this list.

javadoc.text: Appends the part of the specified list between from (inclusive) and to (inclusive) to the receiver.
javadoc.param: other the list to be added to the receiver.
from the index of the first element to be appended (inclusive).
to the index of the last element to be appended (inclusive).
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>other.size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=other.size())</tt>).

javadoc.text: Inserts the specified element before the specified position into the receiver. * Shifts the element currently at that position (if any) and * any subsequent elements to the right.
javadoc.param: index index before which the specified element is to be inserted (must be in [0,size]).
element element to be inserted.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>index < 0 || index > size()</tt>).

javadoc.text: Inserts the part of the specified list between otherFrom (inclusive) and otherTo (inclusive) before the specified position into the receiver. * Shifts the element currently at that position (if any) and * any subsequent elements to the right.
javadoc.param: index index before which to insert first element from the specified list (must be in [0,size])..
other list of which a part is to be inserted into the receiver.
from the index of the first element to be inserted (inclusive).
to the index of the last element to be inserted (inclusive).
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>other.size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=other.size())</tt>).
IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>index < 0 || index > size()</tt>).

javadoc.text: Inserts length dummies before the specified position into the receiver. * Shifts the element currently at that position (if any) and * any subsequent elements to the right.
javadoc.param: index index before which to insert dummies (must be in [0,size])..
length number of dummies to be inserted.

javadoc.text: Searches the receiver for the specified value using * the binary search algorithm. The receiver must be sorted into ascending order * according to the natural ordering of its elements (as by the sort method) * prior to making this call. * If it is not sorted, the results are undefined: in particular, the call * may enter an infinite loop. If the receiver contains multiple elements * equal to the specified object, there is no guarantee which instance * will be found.
javadoc.param: key the value to be searched for.
javadoc.return: index of the search key, if it is contained in the receiver; * otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1). The insertion * point is defined as the the point at which the value would * be inserted into the receiver: the index of the first * element greater than the key, or receiver.size(), if all * elements in the receiver are less than the specified key. Note * that this guarantees that the return value will be >= 0 if * and only if the key is found.

javadoc.text: Searches the receiver for the specified value using * the binary search algorithm. The receiver must be sorted into ascending order * according to the natural ordering of its elements (as by the sort method) * prior to making this call. * If it is not sorted, the results are undefined: in particular, the call * may enter an infinite loop. If the receiver contains multiple elements * equal to the specified object, there is no guarantee which instance * will be found.
javadoc.param: key the value to be searched for.
from the leftmost search position, inclusive.
to the rightmost search position, inclusive.
javadoc.return: index of the search key, if it is contained in the receiver; * otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1). The insertion * point is defined as the the point at which the value would * be inserted into the receiver: the index of the first * element greater than the key, or receiver.size(), if all * elements in the receiver are less than the specified key. Note * that this guarantees that the return value will be >= 0 if * and only if the key is found.

javadoc.text:
Searches the receiver for the specified value using * the binary search algorithm. The receiver must be sorted into ascending order * according to the specified comparator. All elements in the * range must be mutually comparable by the specified comparator * (that is, c.compare(e1, e2) must not throw a * ClassCastException for any elements e1 and * e2 in the range).

* If the receiver is not sorted, the results are undefined: in particular, the call * may enter an infinite loop. If the receiver contains multiple elements * equal to the specified object, there is no guarantee which instance * will be found.
javadoc.param: key the value to be searched for.
from the leftmost search position, inclusive.
to the rightmost search position, inclusive.
comparator the comparator by which the receiver is sorted.
javadoc.throws: ClassCastException if the receiver contains elements that are not * mutually comparable using the specified comparator.
javadoc.return: index of the search key, if it is contained in the receiver; * otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1). The insertion * point is defined as the the point at which the value would * be inserted into the receiver: the index of the first * element greater than the key, or receiver.size(), if all * elements in the receiver are less than the specified key. Note * that this guarantees that the return value will be >= 0 if * and only if the key is found.

javadoc.text: Returns true if the receiver contains the specified element. * Tests for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality.
javadoc.param: element element to search for.
testForEquality if true -> test for equality, otherwise for identity.

javadoc.text: Deletes the first element from the receiver that matches the specified element. * Does nothing, if no such matching element is contained. * Tests elements for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality. * When testing for equality, two elements e1 and * e2 are equal if (e1==null ? e2==null : * e1.equals(e2)).)
javadoc.param: testForEquality if true -> tests for equality, otherwise for identity.
element the element to be deleted.

javadoc.text: Returns the elements currently stored, including invalid elements between size and capacity, if any. * WARNING: For efficiency reasons and to keep memory usage low, the array is not copied. * So if subsequently you modify the returned array directly via the [] operator, be sure you know what you're doing.

Sets the receiver's elements to be the specified array (not a copy of it). * The size and capacity of the list is the length of the array. * WARNING: For efficiency reasons and to keep memory usage low, the array is not copied. * So if subsequently you modify the specified array directly via the [] operator, be sure you know what you're doing.
javadoc.param: elements the new elements to be stored.

javadoc.text: Ensures that the receiver can hold at least the specified number of elements without needing to allocate new internal memory. * If necessary, allocates new internal memory and increases the capacity of the receiver.
javadoc.param: minCapacity the desired minimum capacity.

javadoc.text: Compares the specified Object with the receiver for equality. * Returns true if and only if the specified Object is also an ObjectArrayList, both lists have the * same size, and all corresponding pairs of elements in the two lists are equal. * In other words, two lists are defined to be equal if they contain the * same elements in the same order. * Two elements e1 and * e2 are equal if (e1==null ? e2==null : * e1.equals(e2)).)
javadoc.param: otherObj the Object to be compared for equality with the receiver.
javadoc.return: true if the specified Object is equal to the receiver.

javadoc.text: Compares the specified Object with the receiver for equality. * Returns true if and only if the specified Object is also an ObjectArrayList, both lists have the * same size, and all corresponding pairs of elements in the two lists are the same. * In other words, two lists are defined to be equal if they contain the * same elements in the same order. * Tests elements for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality. * When testing for equality, two elements e1 and * e2 are equal if (e1==null ? e2==null : * e1.equals(e2)).)
javadoc.param: otherObj the Object to be compared for equality with the receiver.
testForEquality if true -> tests for equality, otherwise for identity.
javadoc.return: true if the specified Object is equal to the receiver.

javadoc.text: Sets the specified range of elements in the specified array to the specified value.
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
to the index of the last element (inclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
val the value to be stored in the specified elements of the receiver.

javadoc.text: Applies a procedure to each element of the receiver, if any. * Starts at index 0, moving rightwards.
javadoc.param: procedure the procedure to be applied. Stops iteration if the procedure returns <tt>false</tt>, otherwise continues.
javadoc.return: <tt>false</tt> if the procedure stopped before all elements where iterated over, <tt>true</tt> otherwise.

javadoc.text: Returns the element at the specified position in the receiver.
javadoc.param: index index of element to return.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (index < 0 || index >= size()).

javadoc.text: Returns the element at the specified position in the receiver; WARNING: Does not check preconditions. * Provided with invalid parameters this method may return invalid elements without throwing any exception! * You should only use this method when you are absolutely sure that the index is within bounds. * Precondition (unchecked): index >= 0 && index < size().
javadoc.param: index index of element to return.

javadoc.text: Returns the index of the first occurrence of the specified * element. Returns -1 if the receiver does not contain this element. * Tests for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality.
javadoc.param: testForEquality if true -> test for equality, otherwise for identity.
javadoc.return: the index of the first occurrence of the element in the receiver; returns -1 if the element is not found.

javadoc.text: Returns the index of the first occurrence of the specified * element. Returns -1 if the receiver does not contain this element. * Searches between from, inclusive and to, inclusive. * Tests for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality.
javadoc.param: element element to search for.
from the leftmost search position, inclusive.
to the rightmost search position, inclusive.
testForEquality if true -> test for equality, otherwise for identity.
javadoc.return: the index of the first occurrence of the element in the receiver; returns -1 if the element is not found.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text: Determines whether the receiver is sorted ascending, according to the natural ordering of its * elements. All elements in this range must implement the * Comparable interface. Furthermore, all elements in this range * must be mutually comparable (that is, e1.compareTo(e2) * must not throw a ClassCastException for any elements * e1 and e2 in the array).
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive) to be sorted.
to the index of the last element (inclusive) to be sorted.
javadoc.return: <tt>true</tt> if the receiver is sorted ascending, <tt>false</tt> otherwise.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text: Returns the index of the last occurrence of the specified * element. Returns -1 if the receiver does not contain this element. * Tests for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality.
javadoc.param: element the element to be searched for.
testForEquality if true -> test for equality, otherwise for identity.
javadoc.return: the index of the last occurrence of the element in the receiver; returns -1 if the element is not found.

javadoc.text: Returns the index of the last occurrence of the specified * element. Returns -1 if the receiver does not contain this element. * Searches beginning at to, inclusive until from, inclusive. * Tests for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality.
javadoc.param: element element to search for.
from the leftmost search position, inclusive.
to the rightmost search position, inclusive.
testForEquality if true -> test for equality, otherwise for identity.
javadoc.return: the index of the last occurrence of the element in the receiver; returns -1 if the element is not found.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text:
Sorts the specified range of the receiver into * ascending order, according to the natural ordering of its * elements. All elements in this range must implement the * Comparable interface. Furthermore, all elements in this range * must be mutually comparable (that is, e1.compareTo(e2) * must not throw a ClassCastException for any elements * e1 and e2 in the array).

* This sort is guaranteed to be stable: equal elements will * not be reordered as a result of the sort.

* The sorting algorithm is a modified mergesort (in which the merge is * omitted if the highest element in the low sublist is less than the * lowest element in the high sublist). This algorithm offers guaranteed * n*log(n) performance, and can approach linear performance on nearly * sorted lists. *

You should never call this method unless you are sure that this particular sorting algorithm is the right one for your data set. * It is generally better to call sort() or sortFromTo(...) instead, because those methods automatically choose the best sorting algorithm.
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive) to be sorted.
to the index of the last element (inclusive) to be sorted.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text:
Sorts the receiver according * to the order induced by the specified comparator. All elements in the * range must be mutually comparable by the specified comparator * (that is, c.compare(e1, e2) must not throw a * ClassCastException for any elements e1 and * e2 in the range).

* This sort is guaranteed to be stable: equal elements will * not be reordered as a result of the sort.

* The sorting algorithm is a modified mergesort (in which the merge is * omitted if the highest element in the low sublist is less than the * lowest element in the high sublist). This algorithm offers guaranteed * n*log(n) performance, and can approach linear performance on nearly * sorted lists.
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive) to be * sorted.
to the index of the last element (inclusive) to be sorted.
c the comparator to determine the order of the receiver.
javadoc.throws: ClassCastException if the array contains elements that are not * mutually comparable using the specified comparator.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text: Returns a new list of the part of the receiver between from, inclusive, and to, inclusive.
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive).
to the index of the last element (inclusive).
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text:
Sorts the specified range of the receiver into * ascending order, according to the natural ordering of its * elements. All elements in this range must implement the * Comparable interface. Furthermore, all elements in this range * must be mutually comparable (that is, e1.compareTo(e2) * must not throw a ClassCastException for any elements * e1 and e2 in the array).

* The sorting algorithm is a tuned quicksort, * adapted from Jon L. Bentley and M. Douglas McIlroy's "Engineering a * Sort Function", Software-Practice and Experience, Vol. 23(11) * P. 1249-1265 (November 1993). This algorithm offers n*log(n) * performance on many data sets that cause other quicksorts to degrade to * quadratic performance. *

You should never call this method unless you are sure that this particular sorting algorithm is the right one for your data set. * It is generally better to call sort() or sortFromTo(...) instead, because those methods automatically choose the best sorting algorithm.
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive) to be sorted.
to the index of the last element (inclusive) to be sorted.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text:
Sorts the receiver according * to the order induced by the specified comparator. All elements in the * range must be mutually comparable by the specified comparator * (that is, c.compare(e1, e2) must not throw a * ClassCastException for any elements e1 and * e2 in the range).

* The sorting algorithm is a tuned quicksort, * adapted from Jon L. Bentley and M. Douglas McIlroy's "Engineering a * Sort Function", Software-Practice and Experience, Vol. 23(11) * P. 1249-1265 (November 1993). This algorithm offers n*log(n) * performance on many data sets that cause other quicksorts to degrade to * quadratic performance.
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive) to be sorted.
to the index of the last element (inclusive) to be sorted.
c the comparator to determine the order of the receiver.
javadoc.throws: ClassCastException if the array contains elements that are not * mutually comparable using the specified comparator.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text: Removes from the receiver all elements that are contained in the specified list. * Tests for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality.
javadoc.param: other the other list.
testForEquality if true -> test for equality, otherwise for identity.
javadoc.return: true if the receiver changed as a result of the call.

javadoc.text: Removes from the receiver all elements whose index is between * from, inclusive and to, inclusive. Shifts any succeeding * elements to the left (reduces their index). * This call shortens the list by (to - from + 1) elements.
javadoc.param: from index of first element to be removed.
to index of last element to be removed.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text: Replaces a number of elements in the receiver with the same number of elements of another list. * Replaces elements in the receiver, between from (inclusive) and to (inclusive), * with elements of other, starting from otherFrom (inclusive).
javadoc.param: from the position of the first element to be replaced in the receiver
to the position of the last element to be replaced in the receiver
other list holding elements to be copied into the receiver.
otherFrom position of first element within other list to be copied.

javadoc.text: Replaces the part between from (inclusive) and to (inclusive) with the other list's * part between otherFrom and otherTo. * Powerful (and tricky) method! * Both parts need not be of the same size (part A can both be smaller or larger than part B). * Parts may overlap. * Receiver and other list may (but most not) be identical. * If from > to, then inserts other part before from.
javadoc.param: from the first element of the receiver (inclusive)
to the last element of the receiver (inclusive)
other the other list (may be identical with receiver)
otherFrom the first element of the other list (inclusive)

method.name: replaceFromToWithFromTo
method.comment: avoid stumbling over my own feet

javadoc.text: Replaces the part of the receiver starting at from (inclusive) with all the elements of the specified collection. * Does not alter the size of the receiver. * Replaces exactly Math.max(0,Math.min(size()-from, other.size())) elements.
javadoc.param: from the index at which to copy the first element from the specified collection.
other Collection to replace part of the receiver
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (index < 0 || index >= size()).

javadoc.text: Retains (keeps) only the elements in the receiver that are contained in the specified other list. * In other words, removes from the receiver all of its elements that are not contained in the * specified other list. * Tests for equality or identity as specified by testForEquality.
javadoc.param: other the other list to test against.
testForEquality if true -> test for equality, otherwise for identity.
javadoc.return: true if the receiver changed as a result of the call.

javadoc.text: Reverses the elements of the receiver. * Last becomes first, second last becomes second first, and so on.
Replaces the element at the specified position in the receiver with the specified element.
javadoc.param: index index of element to replace.
element element to be stored at the specified position.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (index * < 0 || index >= size()).

javadoc.text: Replaces the element at the specified position in the receiver with the specified element; WARNING: Does not check preconditions. * Provided with invalid parameters this method may access invalid indexes without throwing any exception! * You should only use this method when you are absolutely sure that the index is within bounds. * Precondition (unchecked): index >= 0 && index < size().
javadoc.param: index index of element to replace.
element element to be stored at the specified position.

javadoc.text: Randomly permutes the part of the receiver between from (inclusive) and to (inclusive).
javadoc.param: from the index of the first element (inclusive) to be permuted.
to the index of the last element (inclusive) to be permuted.
javadoc.exception: IndexOutOfBoundsException index is out of range (<tt>size()>0 && (from<0 || from>to || to>=size())</tt>).

javadoc.text: Returns the number of elements contained in the receiver.
javadoc.returns: the number of elements contained in the receiver.

javadoc.text: Returns a list which is a concatenation of times times the receiver.
javadoc.param: times the number of times the receiver shall be copied.

javadoc.text:
Returns an array containing all of the elements in the receiver in the * correct order. The runtime type of the returned array is that of the * specified array. If the receiver fits in the specified array, it is * returned therein. Otherwise, a new array is allocated with the runtime * type of the specified array and the size of the receiver. *

* If the receiver fits in the specified array with room to spare * (i.e., the array has more elements than the receiver), * the element in the array immediately following the end of the * receiver is set to null. This is useful in determining the length * of the receiver only if the caller knows that the receiver * does not contain any null elements.
javadoc.param: array the array into which the elements of the receiver are to * be stored, if it is big enough; otherwise, a new array of the * same runtime type is allocated for this purpose.
javadoc.return: an array containing the elements of the receiver.
javadoc.exception: ArrayStoreException the runtime type of <tt>array</tt> is not a supertype * of the runtime type of every element in the receiver.

javadoc.text: Returns a java.util.ArrayList containing all the elements in the receiver.
Returns a string representation of the receiver, containing * the String representation of each element.
Trims the capacity of the receiver to be the receiver's current * size. Releases any superfluos internal memory. An application can use this operation to minimize the * storage of the receiver.
